children.subject: When you put it this way, EECS doesn't seem bad at all!

The EECS plans can be tweaked to provide exactly what you want based on your Mathematics background coming into Berkeley. Just replace the non-EECS courses appropriately to reflect L&S college breadth requirements. But I will recommend the same lower-division EECS sequence for L&S CS students because that is really the best way to be adequately prepared. At this point, the within-major course requirements are essentially harmonized across the two majors offered by the EECS department.  

The EECS lower-division and its logic is really simple to understand. There are two 3-course sequences: 61A, 61B, 61C and 16A, 16B, 70. Each of these sequences ramps up difficulty and nurtures students so that they are ready for the next course.  At the last step, the two trilogies interweave somewhat with 61B being gently helpful for 70 as compared to 16B which is directly helpful in terms of core skills. Meanwhile, 16B is gently helpful for 61C while 61B is directly helpful. 

These sample plans are really most helpful in understanding the sequencing of lower-division courses. The deeper logic behind the upper-division is not represented here because at that point, there are many choices and tracks based on your interests across the modeling/math/algorithms, software development, and hardware development pathways. All that can be said confidently about the upper-division is that essentially everyone should take 170.
Are there similar plans available to CS/intended CS students? I remember seeing some my freshman year, but with the site change, I'm not sure where they are now.

history.content:
There is a bug preventing me from getting these on the website tonight, so posting them here with the expectation that folks will be planning their Spring classes this weekend. Please note that these plans are for EECS majors and reflect no new changes in requirements, just a change in course order, as recommended by some of our lower division faculty.

Students with Math 1A completed in high school.pdf

Students with Math 1B completed in high school.pdf

Students without Math 1A or 1B.pdf
history.subject: Updated Sample/Suggested Program Plans for EECS majors
